newsitem.title: CHINA: China mulls cuts in international phone rates.
newsitem.headline: China mulls cuts in international phone rates.

text.p: China is considering cutting fees for international telephone calls by early next year in a bid to make the sector more competitive, the China Daily newspaper said on Tuesday.
The newspaper said that local phone call rates as well as domestic mail rates were likely to be increased.
It gave no indication of the size of the telephone rate revisions though it said the postal rate change would be substantial.

The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications had filed a request with the powerful State Planning Commission to lower International Direct Dialing (IDD) rates by the end of 1996 or early 1997, the newspaper said.
China's state-run international telephone industry is facing increasing competition from call-back services that offer much lower rates.
Charges for local calls would likely be raised because many of China's telecommunications authorities had complained of losses resulting from artificially low rates, the newspaper said.
"This...has forced local phone companies to delay or cancel plans to upgrade telecommunication lines and other facilities, which has affected communications quality," it said.
A telephone call to Japan costs 18.15 yuan ($2.19) per minute while a call to the United States costs 26.25 yuan per minute.
A letter mailed in Beijing to other Chinese cities costs 0.2 yuan.
